lessonOverview.title: Unit 8 - Lesson 2
structures: There are two beds in the bedroom.
A: Are there two beds in the attic?
B: Yes, there are. / No, there aren’t.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six rooms (bedroom, kitchen, living room, bathroom, attic, garage) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Use SB visuals of rooms. Say: “This is the bathroom.” Students repeat, then close books. Teacher says a room, students mime actions done there.
stretchStrategies: “Design Your Dream House” – Logical Room-Item Match
Give each group 6 room names on small paper cards. Groups draw one flashcard at a time (e.g., cupboard, mirror), and must decide as a team which room it goes in and make a sentence:
Add a twist: some flashcards are "wild" (can go in more than one room) and must be justified.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say simple statements about items in rooms using “There are (number) (items) in the (room).” and ask and answer questions using “Are there (number) (items) in the (room)?” with responses like “Yes, there are.” / “No, there aren’t.”
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Write: “There are ___ ___ in the ___.” on board. Model with: “There are two chairs in the kitchen.” Students ask/answer using room/object cards.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “There are ___ ___ in the ___.” and ask and answer using “Are there ___ ___ in the ___?” / “Yes, there are.” / “No, there aren’t.” to talk about items in rooms.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Display yes/no questions: “Are there two sofas in the bedroom?” Students practise in pairs using SB pictures and prompt frames on the board.

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Often confused – Kindergarteners will tend to prefer 'it is' for everything, even though the Vietnamese is very different for the two structures

languageTransferAnalysis.section: 4. Plural forms of it is and there is:
items: Plural forms of these structures do not exist in Vietnamese. It's difficult for kids to remember to produce them, particularly because the plural element comes before the noun phrase. There are two houses
